Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Catching Sequential Speciation in the Act
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the process by which new species evolve (speciation) is a fundamental question in biological sciences. A popular, but largely untested idea is that the formation of one species can catalyze the formation of other species within a community of interacting organisms (sequential speciation). Previous work has shown that a shift of the apple maggot fly from its native hawthorn host plant to the introduced domesticated apple about 150 years ago in the eastern US has induced a sequential host shift in the insect parasite community that attacks the flies. Specifically, as the fly shifts to attacking the fruits of a new host plant, the insect parasites that attack that fly shift in kind. What remains unknown is how general and rapid sequential speciation events are in nature. A powerful approach is to test the sequential speciation hypothesis in a more proximate case in the western US where the fly was recently introduced just 50 years ago. The proposed research will examine changes in the flies and their parasites in this new habitat to better evaluate the rate of speciation.

Understanding the origins of biodiversity is one of the central issues in biological sciences. In this regard, sequential speciation may be particular relevant for understanding biodiversity in general and in particular the astonishing levels of insect biodiversity (estimated 10-30 million species worldwide, the most diverse group of animals on the planet). Additionally, the apple maggot fly and several closely related species are major economic pests of several agricultural crops. Characterization of the origins of the parasitoid community can inform bio-control schemes to help farmers control the fly before it becomes a serious pest in the western United States.

Project Outcome Report

 

Description

A central concept in evolutionary ecology is that ‘biodiversity begets more biodiversity’. As new species form they create new opportunities for others to exploit, potentially catalyzing a chain reaction of speciation events for whole communities of organisms. Such ‘sequential divergence’ may be particularly important for understanding the great diversity of plant-eating insects and their parasites. When plant-eating insects diversify by shifting to attack new plants, new opportunities become available for their parasitoids to follow suit and diversify, as well. Previous work has demonstrated genetic, behavioral, and diapause differences among the parasitoid wasps attacking Rhagoletis fruit flies in the eastern United States, including the hawthorn and recently formed apple-infesting host races of R. pomonella, consistent with the sequential hypothesis. Establishing the generality of sequential divergence for an even more recent example of host shifting involving R. pomonella flies and their parasitoids in the western U.S was the goal of the project.  

Fifty years ago, R. pomonella was introduced into the Pacific Northwest via larval-infested apples. Here, the fly has formed two new races by shifting from apple to attack black hawthorn and introduced ornamental hawthorn. Black and ornamental hawthorn flies in the Pacific Northwest are attacked by three wasps. However, apple flies are not, implying that the wasps were not introduced along with apple flies but instead originated via shifts from the native snowberry fly, R. zephyria, a sibling species that co-occurs with R. pomonella in the Pacific Northwest.

The goal of the project was to determine whether snowberry-fly attacking wasps have sequentially radiated by shifting to attack black and ornamental hawthorn flies. To accomplish this, the DNA of wasps was sequenced to test for evidence of genetic differences. In addition, eclosion times of wasps (when they come out of the ground after they overwinter) was measured to test whether they have evolved differences in this trait allowing them to track the eclosion times of their respective fly hosts. Finally, behavioral be assays were performed to test if the parasitoids prefer the odors emitted from the fruits of their host flies and avoid non-natal fruit odors.
